class="sc-141ft0t-11 CevKp"><svg height="19px" width="19px" class="sc-141ft0t-12 kmrerB"><use href="/sprite.svg#info-icon"></use></svg></div><div role="tooltip" aria-hidden="true" id="tooltip-kelly-gonsalves" class="sc-141ft0t-10 jlIEAj"><div class="sc-141ft0t-8 sc-141ft0t-9 jPkJJD hNOFxm">Contributing Sex & Relationships Editor</div><div>Kelly Gonsalves is a sex educator, relationship coach, and journalist. She received her journalism degree from Northwestern University, and her writings on sex, relationships, identity, and wellness have appeared at The Cut, Vice, Teen Vogue, Cosmopolitan, and elsewhere.</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><span><div class="sc-1l4o0aw-0 domssK"><div class="sc-1l4o0aw-6 fkjfCN">August 23, 2025</div><div class="sc-1l4o0aw-4 jxiIdI">We carefully vet all products and services featured on mindbodygreen using our<!-- --> <a href="/commerce-guidelines" title="mindbodygreen Commerce Guidlines" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer" class="sc-1l4o0aw-5 eGzVfF">commerce guidelines.</a> <!-- -->Our selections are never influenced by the commissions earned from our links.</div></div></span><span id="content"><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>If you've ever gone through the experience of looking for romantic partners on a dating app, you've probably encountered profiles that just <em>screamed </em>catfish—aka a fake profile, robot, or other type of scam. But research suggests some personality types are more likely than others to fall for a catfish.</p></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>Catfishing, aka online romantic fraud, is still alive and well these days. <a href="https://www.consumer.ftc.gov/blog/2018/07/online-love-asking-money-its-scam" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.consumer.ftc.gov/blog/2018/07/online-love-asking-money-its-scam">According to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission</a>, online romance scams reported to the FBI tripled between 2012 and 2016, and the <a href="https://www.bbb.org/globalassets/article-library/romance-scam-study/bbb-study-online-romance-scams-study.pdf" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.bbb.org/globalassets/article-library/romance-scam-study/bbb-study-online-romance-scams-study.pdf">Better Business Bureau reports</a> that Americans have reported losses of nearly $1 billion due to romance scams. One company that screens profiles for dating companies told the BBB that 500,000 of the 3.5 million profiles it scans every month are fake.</p></div></span><span></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><h2 id="mbg-jNuZpbQ4v" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 grQSzR">People at risk of getting catfished<br></h2></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>In a <a href="https://clinical-practice-and-epidemiology-in-mental-health.com/VOLUME/16/PAGE/24/" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://clinical-practice-and-epidemiology-in-mental-health.com/VOLUME/16/PAGE/24/">review</a> published last month in the <em>Clinical Practice & Epidemiology in Mental Health </em>journal, researchers culled the scientific literature to identify common trends in the types of people who tend to fall for catfishes. They found and analyzed 12 relevant studies. From these, they found that 63% of social media users report having been a victim of catfishing at least once.</p></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>These were the personality types most likely to fall for a catfish: </p></div></span><span><div class="sc-8nga9g-0 iAMDIl"><ul id="mbg-ixhxp8_pR" class="sc-8nga9g-2 dRpZmg"><li class="sc-8nga9g-3 lkVQbW">Romantics (aka people who tend to idealize romantic relationships and romance in general) </li><li class="sc-8nga9g-3 lkVQbW">People high in neuroticism (aka anxious people or those who deal with a lot of negative feelings in general)</li><li class="sc-8nga9g-3 lkVQbW">Sensation-seeking people</li><li class="sc-8nga9g-3 lkVQbW">Impulsive people</li><li class="sc-8nga9g-3 lkVQbW">People with <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/signs-you-might-have-an-addictive-personality" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/signs-you-might-have-an-addictive-personality">addictive personalities</a></li><li class="sc-8nga9g-3 lkVQbW">People with <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/signs-of-a-codependent-relationship" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/signs-of-a-codependent-relationship">codependent tendencies</a></li></ul></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>Women and middle-aged people were also generally more likely to fall for catfishes than people of other genders and ages. </p></div></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><h2 id="mbg-U9AZMjqTR" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 grQSzR">What to do about it<br></h2></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>The personality traits listed above all have something in common: They're vulnerable to getting swept up in an exciting new romance easily.</p></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>"The scammer always acts empathetically and attempts to create the impression in the victim that the two are perfectly synced in their shared view of life," the researchers write in the paper on their findings. "The declarations of the scammer become increasingly affectionate and...a declaration of love is made within two weeks from initial contact."</p></div></span><span></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>So if you fall into any of the above categories, it doesn't hurt to make sure you take budding relationships slowly—and not just to avoid getting catfished! Rushing into relationships too quickly can generally be a recipe for disaster, exposing you to the risk of becoming <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/is-it-love-or-emotional-dependency-how-to-tell" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/is-it-love-or-emotional-dependency-how-to-tell">emotionally dependent</a>, getting attached to <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/emotionally-unavailable-what-it-means-and-15-signs-to-look-for" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/emotionally-unavailable-what-it-means-and-15-signs-to-look-for">emotionally unavailable</a> people, and other common relationship troubles.</p></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>In her book <a href="https://www.amazon.com/Love-Skills-Unlocking-Lasting-Wholehearted/dp/160868623X/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?tag=mind0a3-20" target="_blank" rel="sponsored" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.amazon.com/Love-Skills-Unlocking-Lasting-Wholehearted/dp/160868623X/ref=as_li_qf_sp_asin_il_tl?tag=mind0a3-20"><em>Love Skills</em></a><em>,</em> marriage therapist <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/wc/linda-carroll" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/wc/linda-carroll">Linda Carroll, LMFT</a>, recommends <em>all </em>people in the earlier honeymoon stage of their relationship <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/why-trusting-your-heart-wont-help-you-find-a-good-relationship" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/why-trusting-your-heart-wont-help-you-find-a-good-relationship">avoid trusting only their heart</a>.</p></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>"Beware of the fantasy of permanent bliss that this stage wraps you up in," she writes. "That spectacular spike in feel-good neurochemicals can overpower common sense. … Take time to step back and observe your emotions and behaviors; ask yourself whether they're objectively rational. Ask a trusted friend for a candid opinion about your relationship. Awareness is key."</p></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>Oh, and definitely don't send money to a person you met online that you've never met in person before. Good rule of thumb!</p></div></span><span></span></div><aside class="sc-1jito7k-0 jtiNol"></aside></div><div class="sc-11rlt5o-5 gkrCiI"><div class="sc-11rlt5o-6 cbviYE"></div><aside Loewe","sameAs":["https://www.mindbodygreen.com/wc/emma-loewe","https://instagram.com/emmloewe"],"url":"http://www.emmaloewe.com","image":"https://mindbodygreen-res.cloudinary.com/images/c_fill,w_250,h_250,g_face:center,q_85,fl_lossy,f_jpg/usr/R0uOmFQ/Emma Loewe.png"},"articleBody":"How To Keep Inflammation In Check After Exercise: Recovery & Supplement Ideas \"Inflammation\" is almost always presented as a bad thing—but it's not always something to avoid. Following a tough workout, for example, some inflammation is to be expected and is a sign that your muscles are reacting to the stimulus appropriately.\"To repair damaged muscles, your body responds with acute inflammation to absorb the damaged cells and get rid of them. This breakdown and repair process is how you gradually get stronger, fitter, and grow muscle,\" holistic nutritionist and athlete Melissa Boufounos, CHN, previously explained on mindbodygreen. While you don't need to feel sore to know you had a good workout, a little tenderness is nothing to avoid.However, research shows that in some cases, workouts can contribute to chronically high levels of inflammatory markers that increase your risk of injury and may even prompt catabolism, or the breakdown of muscle tissue.Here's how to avoid chronic inflammation following exercise—and how a supplement might help. How to reduce inflammation after tough exercise The best way to combat chronic inflammation and maintain a healthy inflammatory response is to give your body adequate time to recover from exercise.This means spacing out your tougher workouts, prioritizing high-quality sleep, and rehydrating quickly.Your nutrition makes a big difference too. An \"anti-inflammatory diet\" usually consists of plenty of protein (30+ grams a meal), fiber, and healthy fats and is low in processed foods, refined sugars, and trans fats.Certain supplements have also been shown to decrease markers of inflammation following exercise, including creatine. Creatine's anti-inflammatory effects for recovery A review published in the journal Nutrients found evidence that creatine supplementation has anti-inflammatory and anti-catabolic effects. Creatine plays a critical role in the production of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the body's primary energy source. Our bodies naturally produce creatine, but supplemental creatine is also widely available and relatively affordable.\"The number of studies examining the anti-inflammatory effects of creatine supplementation in various disease and exercise states continues to grow with promising results,\" the Nutrients review reads. For example, one randomized controlled trial found that supplementing with creatine during half-ironman training was associated with lower inflammatory markers post-race.And it's not just extreme endurance athletes who could benefit from adding creatine to their recovery routine. Beyond preventing muscle breakdown (catabolism), creatine also seems to increase measures of muscle mass and performance in adults of all ages and fitness levels when combined with resistance exercise.Research shows that adding creatine to your training routine can increase muscular strength in as little as two weeks, as well as support a greater reduction in body fat percentage than resistance training alone.Moral of the story: If you're bumping up your time in the gym, creatine may help reduce the negative wear-and-tear of training and increase its positive effects. The supplement is considered very safe in the fitness community, and taking 3-5 grams per day seems to be a sweet spot for everyday athletes looking for performance and recovery benefits.RELATED READ: The 5 Best Creatine Supplements For Women The takeaway Eating well, sleeping enough, and hydrating are essential after tough workouts. If you're looking to amp up your recovery routine even more, you can also consider taking supplemental creatine.There's emerging research to show the muscle-supporting supplement touts particular benefits for women—learn about that here. Emma received her B.A. in Environmental Science & Policy with a specialty in environmental communications from Duke University. gjIquG"><p>"Inflammation" is almost always presented as a bad thing—but it's not always something to avoid. Following a tough workout, for example, some inflammation is to be expected and is a sign that your muscles are reacting to the stimulus appropriately.</p></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>"To repair damaged muscles, your body responds with acute inflammation to absorb the damaged cells and get rid of them. This breakdown and repair process is how you gradually get stronger, fitter, and grow muscle," holistic nutritionist and athlete <a href="https://melissaboufounos.com/" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://melissaboufounos.com/">Melissa Boufounos, CHN</a>, <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/how-to-relieve-sore-muscles" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/how-to-relieve-sore-muscles">previously explained on mindbodygreen</a>. While you don't<em> need</em> to feel sore to know you had a good workout, a little tenderness is nothing to avoid.</p></div></span><span></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>However, research shows that in some cases, workouts can contribute to <span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6962351/" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" tissue.</p></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>Here's how to avoid chronic inflammation following exercise—and how a supplement might help.</p></div></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><h2 id="mbg-rOaM2EDUy" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 grQSzR">How to reduce inflammation after tough exercise</h2></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>The best way to combat chronic inflammation and maintain a healthy inflammatory response is to give your body adequate time to recover from exercise.</p></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>This means <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/how-long-to-rest-between-weightlifting" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/how-long-to-rest-between-weightlifting">spacing out your tougher workouts</a>, <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/15-ways-to-get-high-quality-sleep" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/15-ways-to-get-high-quality-sleep">prioritizing high-quality sleep</a>, and <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/how-to-rehydrate" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/how-to-rehydrate">rehydrating quickly</a>.</p></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>Your nutrition makes a big difference too. An "<a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/anti-inflammatory-diet-meal-plan" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/anti-inflammatory-diet-meal-plan">anti-inflammatory diet</a>" usually consists of plenty of <a Loewe","sameAs":["https://www.mindbodygreen.com/wc/emma-loewe","https://instagram.com/emmloewe"],"url":"http://www.emmaloewe.com","image":"https://mindbodygreen-res.cloudinary.com/images/c_fill,w_250,h_250,g_face:center,q_85,fl_lossy,f_jpg/usr/R0uOmFQ/Emma Loewe.png"},"articleBody":"Healthy Planet, Healthy You: January 2023 Climate News To Know Our series Healthy Planet, Healthy You explores just how tightly human health and environmental health are intertwined—for better and for worse. Each month, we'll share the latest news on how nature can rejuvenate us on one hand and damage our health when it's not cared for on the other. We'll end with timely tips and tools to help you care for your environment so it can care for you. We talk a lot about the microplastics in the ocean—but what about the ones in the air? According to a new study out of Auckland, New Zealand, airborne microplastics are more prevalent than we previously thought (or would care to believe). By using an extra-perceptive sensor that could pick up tiny plastic particles as small as 0.01 of a millimeter, researchers found that 74 metric tons of microplastics are dropping out of the atmosphere onto the city annually—roughly the same as 3 million plastic bottles. \"The smaller the size ranges we looked at, the more microplastics we saw. This is notable because the smallest sizes are the most toxicologically relevant,\" lead study author Joel Rindelaub, Ph.D., said in a news release. Scientists are now investigating the toll that breathing in so many plastic particles daily might play on our health over time. (Read the research here.) As the human population grows, nature experiences are harder to come by. How has human interaction with nature changed over the last few decades? That's the question that fueled an ambitious new research project studying how close people live to nature now, compared to 20 years ago. Researchers defined a natural area as one with a low \"human footprint\" (buildings, roads, etc.). They found that the average person currently lives 9.7 kilometers (6 miles) away from a natural area, which is 7% farther away than we did in the year 2000. \"Indeed, the study reveals that the destruction of natural areas combined with a strong increase in urban population is leading to a growing spatial distance between humans and nature, especially in Asia, Africa and South America,\" Gladys Barragan-Jason, Ph.D., a co-author of the study, says in a news release. Barragan-Jason's team found that we might be becoming more emotionally distanced too, as there is proportionally less nature imagery in novels, songs, children's albums, and animated movies these days than there was several decades ago. (Read the research here.) Plankton holds a key to ocean health—and potentially human health too. Researchers at the University of California, San Diego, are now studying a century-old survey of marine plankton to see how it can serve as a time capsule for ocean health. Since these tiny organisms are very sensitive to changes in their environment, they can show how aquatic conditions have been polluted over time. Scientists now wonder if changes in plankton can also show us how human health has declined alongside marine health and if there are any parallels between plankton decline and the increasing rate of chronic illness in humans. (Read the research here.) Climate change will make plants more productive—but that isn't necessarily a good thing. Since carbon is used in photosynthesis, increasing CO2 levels in the atmosphere can help plants grow faster and be more productive. Sounds like a good thing for crops and the food system, right? Not exactly, scientists say. Take this new study out of Michigan State University that found that though carbon dioxide increases photosynthesis, it does so at the expense of other essential metabolic processes in plants. \"Plants like CO2. If you give them more of it, they'll make more food and they'll grow bigger. But what if you get a bigger plant that has a lower protein content? It'll actually be less nutritious,\" Berkley Walker, Ph.D., whose research team authored the report, says in a news release. (Read the research here.) Monthly focus: Climate conversations. Reading about climate change can bring up a wide range of heavy emotions. It's a lot to sit with by yourself. Talking about these issues with others is a healthy way to vent your concerns, support each other, and maybe even come up with some solutions together. Looking to build out your climate community in the new year? Why not start an eco book club?I can say from personal experience (hey, club!) that sharing climate fears and anxieties with other people is extremely cathartic. Book clubs can also be wonderful spaces to share knowledge and resources and discuss how to take inspired action. It doesn't need to be a huge undertaking: Just gathering a few friends to discuss a great climate-focused book every few months can lead to insights. When you're ready to get started, these titles are ready for you. Contributor</div><div>Emma Loewe is the former Sustainability and Health Director at mindbodygreen. She is the author of "Return to Nature: The New Science of How Natural Landscapes Restore Us" and the co-author of "The Spirit Almanac: A Modern Guide To Ancient Self Care."  Emma received her B.A. in Environmental Science & Policy with a specialty in environmental communications from Duke University. In addition to penning over 1,500 mbg articles on topics from the water crisis in California to the rise of urban beekeeping, her work has appeared on Grist, Bloomberg News, Bustle, and Forbes.</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><span><div class="sc-1l4o0aw-0 fEDVkk"><div id="article-header-image" class="sc-11lw232-0 cnAvEr sc-1l4o0aw-1 htCTCn"><picture><source end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><em>Our series </em><em>Healthy Planet, Healthy You</em><em> explores just how tightly human health and environmental health are intertwined—for better and for worse. Each month, we'll share the latest news on how nature can rejuvenate us on one hand and damage our health when it's not cared for on the other. We'll end with timely tips and tools to help you care for your environment so it can care for you.</em></div></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><span class="sc-1osfqhu-1 jvZTrj">1<!-- -->.</span><h2 id="mbg-7t_a14KT_P" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 dGESiN">We talk a lot about the microplastics in the ocean—but what about the ones in the air?</h2></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>According to a new study out of Auckland, New Zealand, airborne microplastics are more prevalent than we previously thought (or would care to believe). By using an extra-perceptive sensor that could pick up tiny plastic particles as small as 0.01 of a millimeter, researchers found that 74 metric tons of microplastics are dropping out of the atmosphere onto the city annually—roughly the same as <a href="https://phys.org/news/2022-12-microplastics-auckland-air-equal-million.html" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://phys.org/news/2022-12-microplastics-auckland-air-equal-million.html">3 million plastic bottles</a>. "The smaller the size ranges we looked at, the more microplastics we saw. This is notable because the smallest sizes are the most toxicologically relevant," lead study author Joel Rindelaub, Ph.D., said in <a href="https://phys.org/news/2022-12-microplastics-auckland-air-equal-million.html" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://phys.org/news/2022-12-microplastics-auckland-air-equal-million.html">a news release</a>. Scientists are now investigating the toll that breathing in so many plastic particles daily might play on our health over time. (<span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36459143/" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36459143/" data-citation-link>Read the research here</a><a href="#citations" data-citation-number="1">1<svg width="11" height="10" viewBox="0 0 11 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10.5616 1.47255C10.7935 1.16327 10.7308 0.724508 10.4216 0.492549C10.1123 0.26059 9.67352 0.323271 9.44156 0.63255L4.41852 7.32996L2.03106 4.54448C1.77947 4.25094 1.33756 4.21694 1.04403 4.46853C0.750497 4.72012 0.716495 5.16203 0.968084 5.45556L3.77335 8.72851C3.81859 8.84955 3.89785 8.9595 4.0089 9.04279C4.09758 9.1093 4.19691 9.15159 4.29895 9.17078C4.51931 9.23643 4.76744 9.19227 4.955 9.03151C5.07764 8.92639 5.15498 8.78804 5.18511 8.64118L10.5616 1.47255Z" /></svg></a></span>.)</p></div></span><span></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><span class="sc-1osfqhu-1 jvZTrj">2<!-- -->.</span><h2 id="mbg-p9FHJY66P3" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 dGESiN">As the human population grows, nature experiences are harder to come by.</h2></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>How has human interaction with nature changed over the last few decades? That's the question that fueled an ambitious new research project studying how close people live to nature now, compared to 20 years ago. Researchers defined a natural area as one with a low "human footprint" (buildings, roads, etc.). They found that the average person currently lives 9.7 kilometers (6 miles) away from a natural area, which is 7% farther away than we did in the year 2000. "Indeed, the study reveals that the destruction of natural areas combined with a strong increase in urban population is leading to a growing spatial distance between humans and nature, especially in Asia, Africa and South America," Gladys Barragan-Jason, Ph.D., a co-author of the study, says in <a href="https://www.eurekalert.org/news-releases/974388" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.eurekalert.org/news-releases/974388">a news release</a>. Barragan-Jason's team found that we might be becoming more emotionally distanced too, as there is proportionally less nature imagery in novels, songs, children's albums, and animated movies these days than there was several decades ago. (<a href="https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/fee.2540" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/fee.2540">Read the research here</a>.)</p></div></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><span class="sc-1osfqhu-1 jvZTrj">3<!-- -->.</span><h2 id="mbg-9J3WKmrHyb" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 dGESiN">Plankton holds a key to ocean health—and potentially human health too.</h2></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>Researchers at the University of California, San Diego, are now studying a century-old survey of marine plankton to see how it can serve as a time capsule for ocean health. Since these tiny organisms are very sensitive to changes in their environment, they can show how aquatic conditions have been polluted over time. Scientists now wonder if changes in plankton can also show us how human health has declined alongside marine health and if there are any parallels between plankton decline and the increasing rate of chronic illness in humans. (<span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0048969722083267?via%3Dihub" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0048969722083267?via%3Dihub" data-citation-link>Read the research here</a><a href="#citations" data-citation-number="2">2<svg width="11" height="10" viewBox="0 0 11 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10.5616 1.47255C10.7935 1.16327 10.7308 0.724508 10.4216 0.492549C10.1123 0.26059 9.67352 0.323271 9.44156 0.63255L4.41852 7.32996L2.03106 4.54448C1.77947 4.25094 1.33756 4.21694 1.04403 4.46853C0.750497 4.72012 0.716495 5.16203 0.968084 5.45556L3.77335 8.72851C3.81859 8.84955 /></svg></a></span>.)</p></div></span><span></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><span class="sc-1osfqhu-1 jvZTrj">4<!-- -->.</span><h2 id="mbg-y1eVuVs19V" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 dGESiN">Climate change will make plants more productive—but that isn't necessarily a good thing.</h2></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>Since carbon is used in photosynthesis, increasing CO<sub>2</sub> levels in the atmosphere can <span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fphys.2017.00578/full" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fphys.2017.00578/full" data-citation-link>help plants grow faster and be more productive</a><a href="#citations" data-citation-number="3">3<svg width="11" height="10" viewBox="0 0 11 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10.5616 1.47255C10.7935 1.16327 10.7308 0.724508 10.4216 0.492549C10.1123 0.26059 9.67352 0.323271 9.44156 0.63255L4.41852 7.32996L2.03106 4.54448C1.77947 4.25094 1.33756 4.21694 1.04403 4.46853C0.750497 4.72012 0.716495 5.16203 0.968084 5.45556L3.77335 8.72851C3.81859 8.84955 3.89785 8.9595 4.0089 9.04279C4.09758 9.1093 4.19691 9.15159 4.29895 9.17078C4.51931 9.23643 4.76744 9.19227 4.955 9.03151C5.07764 8.92639 5.15498 8.78804 5.18511 8.64118L10.5616 1.47255Z" /></svg></a></span>. Sounds like a good thing for crops and the food system, right? Not exactly, scientists say. Take this new study out of Michigan State University that found that though carbon dioxide increases photosynthesis, it does so at the expense of other essential metabolic processes in plants. "Plants like CO<sub>2</sub>. If you give them more of it, they'll make more food and they'll grow bigger. But what if you get a bigger plant that has a lower protein content? It'll actually be less nutritious," Berkley Walker, Ph.D., whose research team authored the report, says in <a href="https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2022/12/221222162410.htm" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2022/12/221222162410.htm">a news release</a>. (<span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41477-022-01294-9" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41477-022-01294-9" grQSzR">Monthly focus: Climate conversations.</h2></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>Reading about climate change can bring up <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/climate-distress-and-anxiety-through-the-ages" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/climate-distress-and-anxiety-through-the-ages">a wide range of heavy emotions</a>. It's a lot to sit with by yourself. Talking about these issues with others is a healthy way to vent your concerns, support each other, and maybe even come up with some solutions together. Looking to build out your climate community in the new year? Why not start an eco book club?</p></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>I can say from personal experience (hey, club!) that sharing climate fears and anxieties with other people is extremely cathartic. Book clubs can also be wonderful spaces to share knowledge and resources and discuss how to take inspired action. It doesn't need to be a huge undertaking: Just gathering a few friends to discuss a great climate-focused book every few months can lead to insights. When you're ready to get started, <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/climate-change-books-the-5-best-ones-of-the-year-so-far" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/climate-change-books-the-5-best-ones-of-the-year-so-far">these titles are ready for you</a>.</p></div></span><span></span></div><aside Wachob","sameAs":["https://www.mindbodygreen.com/wc/jason-wachob","https://twitter.com/jasonwachob","https://instagram.com/jasonwachob"],"url":"http://wellth.mindbodygreen.com","image":"https://mindbodygreen-res.cloudinary.com/images/c_fill,w_250,h_250,g_face:center,q_85,fl_lossy,f_jpg/usr/TByNkSe/Jason Wachob.png"},"articleBody":"4 Surprisingly Easy Foods To Grow Yourself That Pack In Nutrients, From An MD It's no secret that home gardens have exploded in popularity of late—whether you opt for mood-lifting flowers or are partial to edible plant plots. When it comes to the latter, family physician and science journalist Daphne Miller, M.D., welcomes the move toward homegrown harvest: \"I'm seeing this expansion of the terrace, front yard, backyard, side yard, and sidewalk farming movement,\" she says on this episode of the mindbodygreen podcast (indoor windowsill gardens, too!). \"I see that as a really amazing source of both nutrients and beautification in the neighborhood.\" But if you are going to start your own edible home garden, you may wonder: Which healthy plants are the most beginner-friendly? Below, Miller lists a few underrated superstars that are surprisingly easy to nurture. Consider them low-maintenance crops that pack quite a nutritious punch:   Herbs & spices No surprise, Miller is a fan of the humble herb garden: \"The oreganos, the thymes, the rosemaries, the alliums—all of these things that give you a lot of nutrition bang for your buck,\" she says. Let's dip into the research: Studies have shown that the flavonoids and phenolic acid in oregano can help manage inflammation and oxidative stress; thyme has well-documented immune-supporting powers; rosemary touts antioxidant and neuroprotective properties; finally, alliums (think garlic, scallion, shallot, leek, and chives) are chock-full of antioxidant properties—some experts even recommend eating a clove of garlic a day, if you can tolerate the taste. In terms of ease, herbs are notoriously low-maintenance: \"Herbs tend to recede themselves,\" says Miller, and they tend to be perennial (meaning, they live on for multiple growing seasons). See here for how to prep your very own herb garden.  Chayote This Mexican squash is rich in antioxidants, fiber, and phytonutrients—namely, quercetin and myricetin (another powerful flavonoid). One study even found that dried chayote had an antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effect in older adults with metabolic syndrome. The gourd has a flavor akin to a cucumber or jicama, and you can enjoy it cooked or raw—simply snap it right off the vine. Kale Miller also touts the ease of kale trees. For those without a yard, don't worry—these trees typically grow 2 to 3 feet tall, and they're pretty resilient: \"[They] can really take everything from tons of water to a minimum of water,\" says Miller. She continues, \"These perennial trees produce the most delicious, buttery, sweet kale leaves.\" In case you need a refresher on the health benefits of kale, the cruciferous veggie is high in vitamins, antioxidants, and fiber. Often dubbed a \"nutritional powerhouse,\" this is one worthy plant for your home garden.  Nopales Of course, we'd be remiss not to mention cactus, as these \"really take no water,\" says Miller—perfect for the forgetful plant parents among us. Nopales refer to the pads of the cactus, and, according to Miller, are low-glycemic players with tons of antioxidant capabilities; one study even found that the nopal cactus may have neuroprotective properties. \"You can just cut off one pad and actually eat it raw,\" Miller notes. \"There's a great way to prepare it raw and make a salad with it. [It's] delicious with lime or lemon.\" Sounds delightfully thirst-quenching, no? The takeaway. \n \"These are all vegetables that do very well within local soil and give right back in terms of nutrition,\" says Miller. In other words: They don't take much to grow, yet they pack in health benefits. Seems like a sound investment to us. Daphne Miller, M.D. Enjoy this episode sponsored by Cotton! And don't forget to subscribe to our podcast on iTunes, Google Podcasts, or Spotify!  "}</script><style data-styled="" data-styled-version="5.3.11">.hNtrZC{color:#ffffff;background-color:#2260b2;position:relative;display:-webkit-box;display:-webkit-flex;display:-ms-flexbox;display:flex;font-family:Maax,"Helvetica Neue",Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif;-webkit-flex-direction:column;-ms-flex-direction:column;flex-direction:column;padding:2rem 0;}/*!sc*/

Easy Foods To Grow Yourself That Pack In Nutrients, From An MD</h1></div><div class="sc-141ft0t-18 jlNNNa"><div class="sc-141ft0t-0 fyLHEz"><div class="sc-141ft0t-1 cYnehL"><a class="sc-141ft0t-2 Jason Wachob</a></div><div tabindex="0" role="button" aria-label="Show information about Jason Wachob" aria-describedby="tooltip-jason-wachob" class="sc-141ft0t-11 CevKp"><svg height="19px" class="sc-141ft0t-8 sc-141ft0t-9 jPkJJD hNOFxm">mbg Founder & Co-CEO</div><div>Jason Wachob is the Founder and Co-CEO of mindbodygreen and the author of Wellth.</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><span><div class="sc-1l4o0aw-0 fEDVkk"><div id="article-header-image" class="sc-11lw232-0 cnAvEr sc-1l4o0aw-1 htCTCn"><picture><source width="900" height="500" media="(min-width: 1024px)" srcSet="https://mindbodygreen-res.cloudinary.com/image/upload/c_fill,g_auto,w_900,h_500,q_90,f_auto,fl_lossy/org/sojt0m3u4kqi318u6.jpg, https://mindbodygreen-res.cloudinary.com/image/upload/c_fill,g_auto,w_900,h_500,q_90,f_auto,fl_lossy/dpr_2.0/org/sojt0m3u4kqi318u6.jpg 2x"/><source width="1023" height="575" media="(min-width: 768px)" srcSet="https://mindbodygreen-res.cloudinary.com/image/upload/c_fill,g_auto,w_1023,h_575,q_90,f_auto,fl_lossy/org/sojt0m3u4kqi318u6.jpg, https://mindbodygreen-res.cloudinary.com/image/upload/c_fill,g_auto,w_1023,h_575,q_90,f_auto,fl_lossy/dpr_2.0/org/sojt0m3u4kqi318u6.jpg 2x"/><img role="presentation" alt="Daphne Miller, M.D." fetchpriority="high" title="Daphne Miller, M.D." loading="eager" width="480" height="322" src="https://mindbodygreen-res.cloudinary.com/image/upload/c_fill,g_auto,w_480,h_322,q_90,f_auto,fl_lossy/org/sojt0m3u4kqi318u6.jpg" https://mindbodygreen-res.cloudinary.com/image/upload/c_fill,g_auto,w_480,h_322,q_90,f_auto,fl_lossy/dpr_2.0/org/sojt0m3u4kqi318u6.jpg 2x"/></picture></div><div class="sc-1l4o0aw-2 lakBAy"><div class="sc-1l4o0aw-3 hcjugp">Image by mbg creative X Daphne Miller </div></div><div class="sc-1l4o0aw-6 fkjfCN">June 30, 2021</div></div></span><span id="content"><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>It's no secret that home gardens have <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/easy-plants-to-grow-outdoors" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/easy-plants-to-grow-outdoors">exploded in popularity of late</a>—whether you opt for mood-lifting flowers or are partial to edible plant plots. When it comes to the latter, family physician and science journalist <a href="https://www.drdaphne.com/dmmd" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.drdaphne.com/dmmd">Daphne Miller, M.D.,</a> welcomes the move toward homegrown harvest: "I'm seeing this expansion of the terrace, front yard, backyard, side yard, and sidewalk farming movement," she says on this episode of the <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-mindbodygreen-podcast/id1246494475" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-mindbodygreen-podcast/id1246494475">mindbodygreen podcast</a> (indoor windowsill gardens, too!). "I see that as a really amazing source of both nutrients and beautification in the neighborhood." </p></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>But if you are going to start your own edible home garden, you may wonder: Which healthy plants are the <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/low-maintenance-veggies-and-herbs-you-can-grow-late-in-season" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/low-maintenance-veggies-and-herbs-you-can-grow-late-in-season">most beginner-friendly</a>? Below, Miller lists a few underrated superstars that are surprisingly easy to nurture. Consider them low-maintenance crops that pack quite a nutritious punch:  </p></div></span><span></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><span class="sc-1osfqhu-1 jvZTrj">1<!-- -->.</span><h2 id="mbg-WbXSLrkIn" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 dGESiN">Herbs & spices</h2></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>No surprise, Miller is a fan of the humble herb garden: "The oreganos, the thymes, the rosemaries, the alliums—all of these things that give you a lot of nutrition bang for your buck," she says. </p></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>Let's dip into the research: Studies have shown that the flavonoids and phenolic acid in oregano can help manage <span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5874591/#B99-plants-07-00002" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5874591/#B99-plants-07-00002" data-citation-link>inflammation and oxidative stress</a><a href="#citations" data-citation-number="1">1<svg width="11" height="10" viewBox="0 0 11 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10.5616 1.47255C10.7935 1.16327 10.7308 0.724508 10.4216 0.492549C10.1123 0.26059 9.67352 0.323271 9.44156 0.63255L4.41852 7.32996L2.03106 4.54448C1.77947 4.25094 1.33756 4.21694 1.04403 4.46853C0.750497 4.72012 0.716495 5.16203 0.968084 5.45556L3.77335 8.72851C3.81859 8.84955 3.89785 8.9595 4.0089 9.04279C4.09758 9.1093 4.19691 9.15159 4.29895 9.17078C4.51931 9.23643 4.76744 9.19227 4.955 9.03151C5.07764 8.92639 5.15498 8.78804 5.18511 8.64118L10.5616 1.47255Z" /></svg></a></span>; thyme has <span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1018364713000918" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1018364713000918" data-citation-link>well-documented immune-supporting powers</a><a href="#citations" data-citation-number="2">2<svg width="11" height="10" viewBox="0 0 11 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10.5616 1.47255C10.7935 1.16327 10.7308 0.724508 10.4216 0.492549C10.1123 0.26059 9.67352 0.323271 9.44156 0.63255L4.41852 7.32996L2.03106 4.54448C1.77947 4.25094 1.33756 4.21694 1.04403 4.46853C0.750497 4.72012 0.716495 5.16203 0.968084 5.45556L3.77335 8.72851C3.81859 8.84955 3.89785 8.9595 4.0089 9.04279C4.09758 9.1093 4.19691 9.15159 4.29895 9.17078C4.51931 9.23643 4.76744 9.19227 4.955 9.03151C5.07764 8.92639 5.15498 8.78804 5.18511 8.64118L10.5616 1.47255Z" /></svg></a></span>; rosemary touts <span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4749867/" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4749867/" data-citation-link>antioxidant and neuroprotective properties</a><a href="#citations" data-citation-number="3">3<svg width="11" height="10" viewBox="0 0 11 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10.5616 1.47255C10.7935 1.16327 10.7308 0.724508 10.4216 0.492549C10.1123 0.26059 9.67352 0.323271 9.44156 0.63255L4.41852 7.32996L2.03106 4.54448C1.77947 4.25094 1.33756 4.21694 1.04403 4.46853C0.750497 4.72012 0.716495 5.16203 0.968084 5.45556L3.77335 8.72851C3.81859 8.84955 3.89785 8.9595 4.0089 9.04279C4.09758 9.1093 4.19691 9.15159 4.29895 9.17078C4.51931 9.23643 4.76744 9.19227 4.955 9.03151C5.07764 8.92639 5.15498 8.78804 5.18511 8.64118L10.5616 1.47255Z" /></svg></a></span>; finally, alliums (think garlic, scallion, shallot, leek, and chives) are chock-full of antioxidant properties—some experts even recommend <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/anti-inflammatory-diet-guide" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/anti-inflammatory-diet-guide">eating a clove of garlic a day</a>, if you can tolerate the taste. </p></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>In terms of ease, herbs are notoriously low-maintenance: "Herbs tend to recede themselves," says Miller, and they tend to be perennial (meaning, they live on for multiple growing seasons). See here for <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/herb-garden" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/herb-garden">how to prep your very own herb garden</a>. </p></div></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><span class="sc-1osfqhu-1 jvZTrj">2<!-- -->.</span><h2 id="mbg-7ysZxMPxtU" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 dGESiN">Chayote</h2></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>This Mexican squash is rich in antioxidants, fiber, and phytonutrients—namely, <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/what-is-quercetin" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/what-is-quercetin">quercetin</a> and <span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24858497/" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24858497/" data-citation-link>myricetin</a><a href="#citations" data-citation-number="4">4<svg width="11" height="10" viewBox="0 0 11 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10.5616 1.47255C10.7935 1.16327 10.7308 0.724508 10.4216 0.492549C10.1123 0.26059 9.67352 0.323271 9.44156 0.63255L4.41852 7.32996L2.03106 4.54448C1.77947 4.25094 1.33756 4.21694 1.04403 4.46853C0.750497 4.72012 0.716495 5.16203 0.968084 5.45556L3.77335 8.72851C3.81859 8.84955 3.89785 8.9595 4.0089 9.04279C4.09758 9.1093 4.19691 9.15159 4.29895 9.17078C4.51931 9.23643 4.76744 9.19227 4.955 9.03151C5.07764 8.92639 5.15498 8.78804 5.18511 8.64118L10.5616 1.47255Z" /></svg></a></span> (another powerful flavonoid). One study even found that dried chayote had an <span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3921/8/5/146" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3921/8/5/146" data-citation-link>antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effect in older adults with metabolic syndrome</a><a href="#citations" data-citation-number="5">5<svg width="11" height="10" viewBox="0 0 11 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10.5616 1.47255C10.7935 1.16327 10.7308 0.724508 10.4216 0.492549C10.1123 0.26059 9.67352 0.323271 9.44156 0.63255L4.41852 7.32996L2.03106 4.54448C1.77947 4.25094 1.33756 4.21694 1.04403 4.46853C0.750497 4.72012 0.716495 5.16203 0.968084 5.45556L3.77335 8.72851C3.81859 8.84955 3.89785 8.9595 4.0089 9.04279C4.09758 9.1093 4.19691 9.15159 4.29895 9.17078C4.51931 9.23643 4.76744 9.19227 4.955 9.03151C5.07764 8.92639 5.15498 8.78804 5.18511 8.64118L10.5616 1.47255Z" /></svg></a></span>. The gourd has a flavor akin to a cucumber or jicama, and you can enjoy it cooked or raw—simply snap it right off the vine.</p></div></span><span></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><span class="sc-1osfqhu-1 jvZTrj">3<!-- -->.</span><h2 id="mbg-thFr_NLsmg" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 dGESiN">Kale</h2></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>Miller also touts the ease of kale trees. For those without a yard, don't worry—these trees typically grow 2 to 3 feet tall, and they're pretty resilient: "[They] can really take everything from tons of water to a minimum of water," says Miller. </p></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>She continues, "These perennial trees produce the most delicious, buttery, sweet kale leaves." In case you need a refresher on the <a href="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/health-benefits-of-eating-kale" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://www.mindbodygreen.com/articles/health-benefits-of-eating-kale">health benefits of kale</a>, the cruciferous veggie is high in vitamins, antioxidants, and fiber. Often dubbed a "nutritional powerhouse," this is one worthy plant for your home garden. </p></div></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><span class="sc-1osfqhu-1 jvZTrj">4<!-- -->.</span><h2 id="mbg-rWnW-HZfNT" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 dGESiN">Nopales</h2></div></span><span><div end="false" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gjIquG"><p>Of course, we'd be remiss not to mention cactus, as these "really take no water," says Miller—perfect for the forgetful plant parents among us. Nopales refer to the pads of the cactus, and, according to Miller, are low-glycemic players with tons of antioxidant capabilities; one study even found that the nopal cactus may have <span data-citation-wrapper><a href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25232708/" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25232708/" data-citation-link>neuroprotective properties</a><a href="#citations" data-citation-number="6">6<svg width="11" height="10" viewBox="0 0 11 10" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10.5616 1.47255C10.7935 1.16327 10.7308 0.724508 10.4216 0.492549C10.1123 0.26059 9.67352 0.323271 9.44156 0.63255L4.41852 7.32996L2.03106 4.54448C1.77947 4.25094 1.33756 4.21694 1.04403 4.46853C0.750497 4.72012 0.716495 5.16203 0.968084 5.45556L3.77335 8.72851C3.81859 8.84955 3.89785 8.9595 4.0089 9.04279C4.09758 9.1093 4.19691 9.15159 4.29895 9.17078C4.51931 9.23643 4.76744 9.19227 4.955 9.03151C5.07764 8.92639 5.15498 8.78804 5.18511 8.64118L10.5616 1.47255Z" /></svg></a></span>. </p></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>"You can just cut off one pad and actually eat it raw," Miller notes. "There's a great way to prepare it raw and make a salad with it. [It's] delicious with lime or lemon." Sounds delightfully thirst-quenching, no?</p></div></span><span><div class="sc-1osfqhu-0 cIgLuB"><h2 id="mbg-XxOJwdyaAm" class="sc-1osfqhu-3 grQSzR">The takeaway. 
</h2></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p>"These are all vegetables that do very well within local soil and give right back in terms of nutrition," says Miller. In other words: They don't take much to grow, yet they pack in health benefits. Seems like a sound investment to us.</p></div></span><span><div class="sc-dqg2dy-0 kVeYEi"><div class="sc-dqg2dy-2 fooKip"></div></div></span><span><div end="true" class="sc-11rlt5o-4 gGtfNP"><p><em>Enjoy this episode sponsored by </em><a href=" https://thefabricofourlives.com/the-benefits-of-cotton/sustainability?utm_source=mindbod[…]medium=custom&utm_content=linked&utm_campaign=tfol_202104" target="_blank" class="mbg-track-event" data-track-event-types="click" data-track-type="article-link" data-track-prop-element-id="in-body-link" data-track-prop-label="page_type | element_id" data-track-prop-category="Link" data-track-prop-link=" https://thefabricofourlives.com/the-benefits-of-cotton/sustainability?utm_source=mindbod[…]medium=custom&utm_content=linked&utm_campaign=tfol_202104"><em>Cotton</em></a><em>!
